courses.subject: EPID
courses.title: Basic Epidemiology and Health Statistics

courses.description: This course serves as an introduction to epidemiology for students with health services or healthcare experience. The course gives a general overview of epidemiology and biostatistics, including theories and methodologies, and applications in health services management and other healthcare sectors. The course provides the basis for further studies.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Health Services Management and PgD Health Services Management
courses.learning_outcomes:
Student should be able to:
1. appreciate the importance of epidemiology in public health and health services and its limitations
2. describe the various study designs, know their advantages and limitations and how to interpret their results
3. understand basic epidemiological theories, concepts, and methods as applied to health services
4. learn the valid methods for estimating the frequency of disease, and for comparing between groups and populations, learn possible biases and their control methods in the estimation and comparisons
5. apply quantitative methods to address practical public health and health services management issues
6. identify and appraise findings from health services research
courses.course_syllabus:
Measure Disease Frequency

Diagnostic Quiz (not for grading purposes)
Methods of standardization / Sources of Routine Data in Epidemiology

Tutorial
HW #1 based upon lectures 1-3 distributed:
Intro to Descriptive Studies/ Data Collection & Methods used in epidemiology & Information Bias
Tutorial
Cohort Studies/Sampling Methods used in Epidemiology (with intro to Selection Bias)

Tutorial HW #1 due /
HW#2 based upon lectures 4-6 distributed
Randomized Controlled Trials

Tutorial
Case-Control Studies/ Effect Modification & Confounding Issues in Epidemiology

Tutorial
Systematic Review, Hierarchy of Evidence, Brief Introduction to Cause Inference

Tutorial HW #2 due
Extra Optional Tutorial Session (Q&A) HW #2 returned

Midterm Examination (on lectures 1-6)
Introduction to Health Statistics I
Introduction to Health Statistics II

Introduction to Health Statistics III

Health statistics take-home examination distributed.
Due in 2 weeks.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Course evaluation will be done at the end of the course.
courses.required_readings: Given in Class by lecturers. No required textbooks.
courses.recommended_readings:
(1) Hennekens CH, Buring JE. Epidemiology in Medicine. Sherry L. Mayrent, Ed. Little, Brown & Co. Boston, 1987.
(2) Leon Gordis. Epidemiology. W B Saunders, 4th Edition, 2008 Robert (3) H. Fletcher, Suzanne W. Fletcher, Edward H. Wagner. Clinical Epidemiology-The Essentials. 5th Edition, 2005.

courses.description: This course will introduce basic epidemiology to students including introduction to epidemiology, applied health research methods, designing and conducting epidemiological studies (descriptive, case-control, cohort, clinical trials and meta-analysis).
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Public Health, PgD in Public Health, MSc in Epidemiology & Biostatistics or PgD in Epidemiology & Biostatistics
courses.learning_outcomes:
Student should be able to:
1. appreciate the importance of epidemiology in clinical medicine as well as in public health
2. describe the various study designs, know their advantages and limitations and how to interpret their results
3. understand basic epidemiological theories, concepts, and methods as applied to health conditions
4. learn the valid methods for estimating the frequency of disease, the effect of a cause or a treatment, and for comparing between groups and populations
5. learn possible biases and their control methods in the estimation and comparisons
6. apply epidemiological methods to address practical health issues and understand their limitations
7. identify and appraise findings from epidemiological research for application
courses.course_syllabus:
Measure Disease Frequency
Diagnostic Quiz (not for grading purposes)
Methods of standardization / Sources of Routine Data in Epidemiology

Tutorial
HW #1 based upon lectures 1-3 distributed
Intro to Descriptive Studies/ Data Collection & Methods used in epidemiology & Information Bias
Tutorial
Cohort Studies/ Sampling methods used in Epidemiology (with intro to Selection Bias)

Tutorial HW #1 due /
HW #2 based upon lectures 4-6 distributed
Randomized Controlled Trials
Tutorial
Case-Control Studies/ Effect Modification & Confounding Issues in Epidemiology
Tutorial
Systematic Review, Hierarchy of Evidence, Brief Introduction to Cause Inference

Tutorial & Review of HW #1
HW #2 due / HW #1 returned
Extra Optional Tutorial Session (Q&A)

Midterm Examination
Introduction to Screening & Diagnosis

HW #3 based on lectures 7, 9-10 distributed

Tutorial
Introduction to Infectious Disease epidemiology & Outbreak Investigation
HW #3 due
Overview of Research Ethics for Human Studies\*\*
Before class quick reading (see below /Feedback & Final Examination Information
HW #3 returned
Review of HW #2 & 3 and Midterm/ Q&A
Final Examination

courses.required_readings: Given in Class by lecturers. No required textbooks.
courses.recommended_readings:
(1) Hennekens CH, Buring JE. Epidemiology in Medicine. Sherry L. Mayrent, Ed. Little, Brown & Co. Boston, 1987.
(2) Leon Gordis. Epidemiology. W B Saunders, 4th Edition, 2008 Robert (3) H. Fletcher, Suzanne W. Fletcher, Edward H. Wagner. Clinical Epidemiology-The Essentials. 5th Edition, 2005.

courses.description: This is an intermediate module which builds on the content of Introduction to Epidemiology (EPID5001). This module aims to provide students with further knowledge on cross sectional studies, cohort studies, randomized controlled trials, and systematic reviews.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Public Health, PgD in Epidemiology & Biostatistics or MSc in Epidemiology & Biostatistics
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To acquire knowledge on intermediate design and bias reduction methods of cross sectional studies, cohort studies, randomized controlled trials, and systematic reviews

2. Apply intermediate epidemiological concepts and techniques in the planning of epidemiologic studies
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Cross sectional studies

2. Systematic review: literature search and study selection

3. Concepts of RCT –beyond the basics

4. Case examples of RCT (design, data analysis and interpretation)

5. Systematic review: data extraction and risk of bias assessment

6. Longitudinal Cohort Studies I

7. Extensions to the design of case-control studies
courses.feedback_evaluation: Evaluation will be sent to students in the last lecture
courses.required_readings: To be provided by teachers in each session

courses.description: Students shall learn how to conduct common statistical analyses of epidemiological data by using SPSS or other statistical software and to prepare scientific reports for publication. Sessions will consist of brief introduction of the concepts, computer demonstration and data analysis practicum. The session on reporting will be introduce international guidelines for drafting publications for systematic reviews and randomized trials.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Public Health, PgD in Epidemiology & Biostatistics or MSc in Epidemiology & Biostatistics
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Conduct data cleaning, data management and analysis for an epidemiological study using statistical software
2. Compare pros and cons of different analytical methods
3. Be able to present data in tables and figures in proper format for publishing in peer-reviewed journal
4. Acquire skills in using reporting guidelines for systematic reviews and randomized trials
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Data Management with SPSS (I)

2. Data Management with SPSS (II)

3. Systematic review: data analysis

4. Systematic review: PRISMA reporting guideline

5. Tutorial on RCT data analysis

6. Longitudinal Cohort studies II

7. Longitudinal Cohort studies III

8. Data analysis of Case control studies

9. Critical appraisal of a case-control study

10. Diagnostic accuracy study and randomized controlled trial for screening: data analysis

11. Data presentation and visualization
courses.feedback_evaluation: Evaluation will be sent to students in the last lecture
courses.required_readings: To be given by individual lecturers in class

courses.subject: EPID
courses.title: Appraisal of the Methods of Epidemiological Studies

meetings.instructor:
Dr. WANG Jingxuan, 
Miss CHIU Ka Man, 
Ms. Prisana PAVIVAN, 
Ms. YEUNG Tsz Yan, 
Professor CHAN Yan Chim, 
Professor TSOI Kam Fai, 
Professor WANG Zixin, 
Professor WONG Tze Wai, 
Professor YANG Zuyao

courses.description: The course will include a series of tutorials for appraising the methods of commonly used epidemiological study designs. In each tutorial, a published study of a specific design (e.g., randomized controlled trial) will be selected and presented and questions regarding the methods of the study will be asked. Students need to carefully read and discuss the questions beforehand and further discuss with the tutor and peers in the class.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc/PgD in Epidemiology and Biostatistics, MPhil in Public Health, PhD in Public Health, Master of Public Health, PgD in Public Health, MSc/PgD in Health Services Management, MSc/PgD in Health Promotion and Behavioural Health
courses.course_syllabus:
Introduction and General Guideline
Ecological study
Clinical trial/ RCT
Case-control study
Cohort study
Cross-sectional study
Systematic review
Prognostic study
Examination (TBC)
courses.feedback_evaluation: Course evaluation will be done at the end of the course.
courses.required_readings: Given in Class by lecturers. No required textbooks.
courses.recommended_readings:
(1) J. Mark Elwood. Critical appraisal of epidemiological studies and clinical trials. Oxford: Oxford University Press. 3rd Edition, 2007.
(2) David Marchevsky. Critical Appraisal of Medical Literature. Springer. 2000.

courses.description: The course involves a series of guest lecture seminars in which methodological aspects of various areas of epidemiological research are discussed and elaborated.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Public Health and MSc in Epidemiology & Biostatistics
courses.learning_outcomes: Students will become familiar with the methodological and substantive issues of conducting epidemiological investigations in various subject areas. The course is structured as a series of seminars with interactive discussion. Students will be asked to read scientific papers that illustrate concepts in class.
courses.course_syllabus:
Introduction / Intro to Nutritional Epidemiology
Intro to Social Epidemiology and its applications
Infectious Disease Epidemiology
MCQ and Short Answer Question #1 (85 min)
Overview of Environmental Epidemiology (90 min)
Overview of Genetic Epidemiology

Digital Epidemiology

Final Take-home Assignment Distribute & Due in 2 weeks
courses.feedback_evaluation: Course evaluation will be done at the end of the course
courses.required_readings: Given in Class by lecturers. No required textbooks.

courses.subject: EPID
courses.title: Nutritional Epidemiology

meetings.instructor:
Dr. LO Ka Hei Kenneth, 
Miss CHIU Ka Man, 
Ms. Prisana PAVIVAN, 
Ms. YEUNG Tsz Yan

courses.description: In this course, you will learn about the methods used to assess dietary intakes and how to overcome limitations in assessing such a complex ‘exposure’. Nutrient intakes and dietary patterns in different population groups will be illustrated and key diet-disease associations will be presented. Finally, some of the challenges in interpreting nutritional epidemiology evidence and practical issues in communicating findings will be covered.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Public Health, MSc in Epidemiology & Biostatistics
courses.learning_outcomes:
Student should be able to:
1. understand the different methods that are used to examine dietary intake
2. describe key limitations in estimating dietary intake and how these may be minimised in practice
3. explain current evidence relating to how dietary choices impact obesity, CVD and malnutrition
4. apply knowledge to design either an observational assessment of diet or a dietary intervention study

學院本課程之後，學生應該能夠：
1. 理解飲食攝入量的不同評估方法
2. 描述飲食攝入量評估的主要問題以及如何在實際研究中減少此類問題
3. 解釋現有的關於飲食選擇與肥胖、心血管疾病及營養不良的關係的證據
4. 運用所學知識設計一個有關飲食的的觀察性研究或干預研究
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Overview of nutrition and human health

2. Overview of nutritional epidemiology and methods of dietary assessment

3. Interpreting diet, patterns and differences among populations

4. Studies in diet-disease relationships

5. Understanding and communicating nutritional evidence

6. Establishing dietary reference values

7. Nutrition epidemiology and policy changes
courses.feedback_evaluation: Evaluation will be sent to students in the last lecture
courses.required_readings:
Chapters 1-8 and 11-13

Willett W. Nutritional Epidemiology (3rd edition) Oxford, Oxford University Press, 2013. [Available as an electronic resource at CUHK library website]

courses.subject: EPID
courses.title: Practice in Systematic Review and Meta-analysis
courses.description: This course is an advanced module for students who are interested in conducting systematic review and meta-analysis. It emphasizes on practical knowledge and skills needed for doing this kind of research: performing exhaustive literature search to identify relevant studies, extracting data from eligible studies, assessing risk of bias, synthesizing data, including meta-analysis, presenting results graphically and tabularly, investigating heterogeneity and potential biases, and publishing manuscripts in peer-reviewed journals. Tutorial materials will be distributed to students for their in-class exercises. Students will be enabled to master the essential skills for doing systematic review and meta-analysis by the end of this module.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Public Health, MSc in Epidemiology & Biostatistics
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this module, student are expected to be able to:
1. formulate a structured research question and develop search strategies according to the question
2. retrieve relevant studies by exhaustive literature search and select eligible studies from them
3. extract data from eligible studies
4. assess risk of bias for randomized controlled trials using appropriate tools
5. synthesize data from eligible studies, including narrative summary and meta-analysis
6. do other related analyses, such as the investigation of publication bias
7. prepare systematic review manuscripts for publication according to relevant guidelines

希望學生學完本課程之後能夠：
1. 為系統綜述提出結構化的研究問題，并據此制定文獻檢索策略
2. 通過全面的文獻檢索，找出系統綜述所需的合格研究
3. 從合格研究中提取有關數據
4. 采用適合的工具，評估隨機對照試驗發生偏倚的風險
5. 合併各個合格研究的數據，包括敘述性總結和薈萃分析
6. 進行其他有關的分析，例如檢測發表偏倚
7. 根據有關指引撰寫可用於發表的系統綜述論文
courses.course_syllabus:
Literature search and study selection
Data extraction
Data analysis and results presentation
Risk of bias assessment
Publishing systematic reviews
Examination (Group exercise and presentation)
courses.feedback_evaluation: Course evaluation will be done at the end of the course.
courses.required_readings:
1. Sutton AJ, Abrans KR, Jones DR, et al. Methods for meta-analysis in medical research. London: Willey, 2000
2. Egger M, Davey Smith G, Altman DG. Systematic Reviews in Health Care: Meta-Analysis in Context (2nd Edition). London: BMJ Publishing Group, 2008
courses.recommended_readings: 1. Julian PT Higgins, Sally Green. Cochrane handbook for systematic reviews of interventions. Chichester: John Wiley &. Sons, 2008

courses.subject: EPID
courses.title: Digital Epidemiology

meetings.instructor:
Miss CHIU Ka Man, 
Ms. Prisana PAVIVAN, 
Ms. YEUNG Tsz Yan, 
Professor TSOI Kam Fai

courses.description: This advanced module introduces the concept of digital epidemiology with new forms of health data and real examples for disease management. The traditional epidemiology consists of studying various risk factors of the general population to study incidence and prevalence. The field of digital epidemiology is new, but has been growing rapidly with the increasing amounts of data generated on the internet, wearable devices, and mobile APPs. Students will explore the feasibility of applications through different real digital examples, including the consideration with data privacy and protection.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For students in MSc in Epidemiology & Biostatistics, Master of Public Health
Pre-requisite: EPID5001, BIOS5001
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Explain the concepts of digital epidemiology and the associated applications of Big Data
2. Design for the framework of epidemiological studies with the use of digital health data
3. Suggest the ways of interpretation for different types of digital health data
4. Plan for the health applications with wearable devices and mobile APPs
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Overview of Digital Epidemiology

2. Electronic Health Records

3. Health Data from the Community

4. Social Media for Disease Management

5. Big Data and Artificial Intelligence

6. Supercomputer and Computing Servers

7. Wearable Devices and Mobile APPs
courses.feedback_evaluation: Evaluation will be sent to students in the last lecture
courses.required_readings: Mainly from academic publication. A full list will be ready before the lecture starts.

courses.subject: EPID
courses.title: Advanced Infectious Disease Epidemiology

meetings.instructor:
Miss CHIU Ka Man, 
Ms. Prisana PAVIVAN, 
Ms. YEUNG Tsz Yan, 
Professor KWOK Kin On

courses.description: This course is designed to enable post-graduate students who have a background in infectious diseases epidemiology to practice their skills in the real-life problem in infectious disease epidemiology. Contemporary statistical and mathematical methods will be introduced for the study of infectious disease epidemiological data. The course is illustrated with many topical examples including COVID-19, SARS, and influenza.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For students in MSc Epidemiology and Biostatistics and Master of Public Health
Pre-requisite: EPID5001
courses.learning_outcomes:
Student should be able to:

1. To acquire knowledge on infectious disease epidemiology
2. To distinguish different modes of infectious disease transmission from the epidemiological data collected, and, interpret their findings and confirm their hypothesis;
3. To apply intermediate statistical and mathematical model to real life practical problems in infectious disease epidemiology.
4. To evaluate the control measures implemented
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Basic epidemic theory
2. Routes of transmission of infectious diseases
3. Overseas experiences of the COVID-19 pandemic and other infectious disease (I)
4. Introduction of mathematical compartmental model and its application
5. Overseas experiences of the COVID-19 pandemic and other infectious disease (II)
6. Local experiences of the COVID-19 pandemic and other infectious disease (II)
courses.feedback_evaluation: Evaluation will be sent to students in the last lecture
courses.required_readings: To be provided by teachers in each session
